title: Bitway1939
author: Bitway1939
content: Hey everyone, I’ve been experimenting with Bitcoin debit cards and wanted to share what I’ve learned. I know a lot of people here prefer to hold, but for those who like to spend BTC directly, these cards actually make it a lot easier.  Instead of manually converting Bitcoin to fiat, these cards do it at the time of purchase. I tested a few in different situations, and here’s what I found:  - Bybit Card worked perfectly at a clothing store. The transaction was instant, and I even got some cashback.  - KAST Card (though it only works with stablecoins) was super smooth for an eBay purchase. Had to convert BTC to USDC first, but once that was done, it worked without issues.  - A friend of mine in Colombia uses RedotPay all the time and says it’s great for managing expenses while spending Bitcoin.  - Crypto.com card surprisingly didn’t work on Uber. Not sure why—maybe someone here knows?  I go into more detail about the experience in a video I made:https://youtu.be/5f1-8yy0cXk . Not trying to shill anything, just sharing what worked and what didn’t.  Anyone else using a Bitcoin debit card? Have you run into any issues, or do you have a favorite?

comments.author: nullama
comments.body: This is basically using fiat for purchasing stuff, and you just automate the selling of your BTC to a centralized platform that already has your Bitcoin.Not your keys, not your coins.A better way to use your sats is to use lightning with a card, like Bolt Card, or a similar one. You can pay with your card in-store by tapping, and it connects directly to your own wallet, and uses your sats from your storage. No third party needed, no dirty fiat conversion.Here's some more info about this:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7SuhEPSMRoAMeet The Bolt Card, an NFC-enabled Lightning cardHow to use those awesome new Bolt Cards without a CoinCorner account
